div.p:
—In the valley of Tachkou
Targanka, at the spot on which stood the workshops for wash-
ing the sand, there was discovered, on the 7th of November,
1842, under the very corner of the building, at three metres
(ten feet) depth, resting upon a stratum of diorite, a mon-
ster lump of gold, weighing two poods, seven Russian pounds,
and 92 zolotniks (79lb 1,625 dec.) This mass has an undu-
lated surface; it is somewhat porous, and free from all trace
of matrix or gangue. The largest lump of native platina
hitherto found in the platiniferous alluvia of Nijni-Taguilsk,
weighs 20 Russian pounds and 34 zolotniks (= 18,319lb.)—
From Humboldt’s new work, entitled “Asie Centrale.”
